channel.title: Nature Materials
channel.description: Nature Materials is a multidisciplinary journal aimed at bringing together cutting-edge research across the entire spectrum of materials science and technology. Nature Materials covers all applied and fundamental aspects of the synthesis/processing, structure/composition, properties and performance of materials. Nature Materials provides a forum for the development of a common identity among materials scientists while encouraging researchers to cross established subdisciplinary lines. To achieve this, Nature Materials takes an interdisciplinary, integrated and balanced approach to all areas of materials research while fostering the exchange of ideas between scientists involved in different communities.

item.title: Large moiré superstructure of stacked incommensurate charge density waves
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02360-1

The authors identify two coexisting incommensurate charge density waves whose interplay leads to joint commensuration and a long-period moiré structure.
item.dc:title: Large moiré superstructure of stacked incommensurate charge density waves
item.dc:creator: B. Q. Lv
Yifan Su

item.title: Amorphous phase-change memory alloy with no resistance drift
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 01 October 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02361-0

Resistance drift, also known as the temporal change in electrical resistance, hampers the application of phase-change materials for neuromorphic computing. Here an amorphous CrTe3 thin film with no resistance drift in the working temperature from −200 °C to 165 °C is reported.
item.dc:title: Amorphous phase-change memory alloy with no resistance drift
item.dc:creator: Xiaozhe Wang

item.title: Mechanical insights from functional materials
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 30 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02378-5

Our knowledge of deformation behaviour in functional materials is pushing the frontiers of mechanics, informing design strategies and enabling scalable manufacturing.
item.dc:title: Mechanical insights from functional materials

item.title: Intrinsic intermolecular photoinduced charge separation in organic radical semiconductors
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 30 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02362-z

Homojunction intermolecular charge separation is reported in photoexcited anion–cation pairs induced by external electric field bias, opening possibilities for light harvesting using molecular semiconductors.
item.dc:title: Intrinsic intermolecular photoinduced charge separation in organic radical semiconductors
item.dc:creator: Biwen Li
Petri Murto
Rituparno Chowdhury
Laura Brown
Yutong Han
Giacomo Londi
David Beljonne
Hugo Bronstein
Richard H. Friend

item.title: Suppression of PCBM dimer formation in inverted perovskite solar cells
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 30 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02368-7

The authors develop a molecular dopant to avoid the dimerization of the electron-selective material phenyl-C61-butyric acid methyl ester, resulting in enhanced stability and efficiency in inverted perovskite solar cells.
item.dc:title: Suppression of PCBM dimer formation in inverted perovskite solar cells

item.title: Ions in solution drive action and satisfaction
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 29 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02341-4

Aqueous electrochemical reactions drive conductance switching, thereby imbuing perception and sensing to neuronal emulators.
item.dc:title: Ions in solution drive action and satisfaction
item.dc:creator: Yu-Hsiang Chiang
Shruti Hariyani
Sarbajit Banerjee

item.title: Mechanically liberating polarization bubbles in van der Waals ferroelectrics
item.content:encoded:
Nature Materials, Published online: 29 September 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02346-z

Spherical polar topological structures are of interest as they could enable high-density memory applications; however, such texture formation requires superlattices with delicately balanced boundary conditions to form. Here it is found that these textures can form in free-standing CuInP2S6, and that mechanical force can generate high-density domains.
item.dc:title: Mechanically liberating polarization bubbles in van der Waals ferroelectrics
